awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase I: Robots and Sensors for the Human Well-being
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed I/UCRC for Robots and Sensors for the Human Well-being (RoSeHuB) will focus on complementing a broad variety of off-the-self sensors with intelligent processing software that enables them to extract useful information about the operating environments in medicine and agriculture. RoSeHuB research will make heavy use of commercial cameras that can work in different parts of the electro-magnetic spectrum (i.e., visible, IR, Thermal, etc.), laser or radar sensors, etc. Sensors or sensor systems may exhibit different degrees of mobility. They may be embedded in robots or flying drones or they may be fixed with limited degrees of motion (PTZ cameras). In the areas of algorithms and learning methods the focus and the challenge is on creating methodologies that can balance real-time operation and computational power while providing high level semantic information either for planning, interaction or situational awareness for human operators. With respect to robots, efforts will focus on building systems with advanced mobility, manipulation, human-machine interaction, and coordination skills.

Robots and sensors can lead to more effective precision agriculture techniques that provide more food than current levels while they save water and prevent soil erosion. Similarly, robots play a critical and growing role in modern medicine, from training the next generation of doctors, dentists, and nurses, to comforting and protecting elderly patients in the early stages of dementia. The proposed Center will attract large companies to the pertinent domains and energize innovative startup companies, both through research and through the production of highly trained graduate students with advanced coursework in sensory-based robotic systems and hands-on exposure to multi-disciplinary, integrative systems. The Center will also fund a projects to pursue new pertinent high-risk initiatives, ensuring that technology continues to meet emerging societal needs. RoSeHuB faculty will aggressively recruit women and minority graduate and undergraduate students and host an annual summer camp for middle-schoolers from underrepresented groups.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The  Phase I ROSEHUB included 5 sites (University of Minnesota-lead, University of Pennsylvania, University of North Carolina Charlotte, Purdue University, and Denver University.) 

ROSEHUB is the only I/UCRC center focusing on applied research that targets automation via integration of robotics, sensing, and analytic/computational methods.  The program plan for Phase I had drawn on the center's unique capabilities on research in such areas as: (i) medical applications, e.g., autism detection, physical rehabilitation, cancer detection, (ii) precision agriculture, e.g., nitrogen deficiency detection, weed detection, crop collection, (iii) environmental monitoring, e.g., cleaning plants from nuclear waste, cleaning lakes of unwanted algae, (iv) infrastructure monitoring, e.g., detection of cracks on large installations by deploying sophisticated planning and navigation, utility pole health detection, and last but not least (v) transportation, e.g., automating the detection of parking space availability at rest truck stops.
We had been constantly witnessing a great excitement and even stronger anticipation on the impact of AI techniques as they are combined with robots and sensor technologies. These technologies are the driving forces enabling automation of processes previously unimaginable i.e., virtual environments, immersion and visualization, Internet of Things (IoT), autonomous driving, medical imaging for cancer detection, environmental monitoring, precision animal agriculture, etc. ROSEHUB and its comprising academic sites possessed the necessary capabilities and world renowned expertise to succeed in this effort.  Specifically, the ROSEHUB center covered an extensive core set of algorithmic and engineering capabilities to support the overall mission. With the strong participation of the private sector ROSEHUB  helped its members in advancing their research agenda. 
The fields of robotics, automation and its associated AI/Machine Learning technologies are moving at a fast pace. However, today the interdisciplinary technologies that had been developed within the ROSEHUB such as new robot (both ground and aerial) designs, control strategies, computer vision, data mining methods, and telecommunications can continue to dramatically impact robotic and automation fields: Medical, Agriculture, Environment, Transportation, Manufacturing.  We strongly feel that this is the right time and the right challenge for ROSEHUB Phase II to direct the scope in all these fields, while we will continue to be on the look-out for other emerging market segments in the future.ROSEHUB Phase I achievements on medical research using computer vision techniques has led us to the conclusion that that the medical filed has a lot to benefit in the future from the technologies to be developed. Cancer Detection and Monitoring Kids at Risk in developing mental disorders have been examples of research that had already made a significant impact (via research in Phase I) on the affected subjects and the medical doctors early predicting the mental condition. Under these programs collaborating with medical experts in the fields of Clinical Pathology and Psychiatry has shown that computer vision algorithms and precision robotics can influence future medical practices. Our Center's research programs targeted the development of systems that augment human capabilities with the objective of leaving the final decision-making to humans before we achieve a state of full automation.

We believe that the research performed in ROSEHUB I not only contributed its member companies but allowed a multitude of undergraduate and graduate students to get hands on experience and actually be hired by the member companies in some cases.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2023
Modified by: Vassilios Morellas
